Description: Device activations that occur when temperature crosses a configured threshold can be classified as temperature-triggered, while activations at stable, moderate temperatures are more likely leak-triggered or manual.
Short rationale: Mainly distinguishes control logic vs leak/manual events; weak but present link to manual behavior.

Description: If device activations consistently occur before pipes hit historically dangerous low temperatures, the freeze alarm strategy is effective.
Short rationale: Evaluates how early alarms fire vs freeze risk; strategy quality, not user behavior.

Description: Periods where temperatures fall below a critical threshold without any device activation represent missed thermal interventions and silent thermal risks.
Short rationale: Flags unprotected low-temp periods; structural risk signal, not personal.

Inference: Cooling or warming rate after thermal actions
Description: For temperature-driven device activations, the rate of temperature change after activation shows how effective the action is at raising or stabilizing pipe temperature.
Short rationale: Measures effect of actions on temperature; device/system performance only.

Description: When a heating device activates in response to low temperatures, a subsequent rise or stabilization of temperature in that segment confirms the device is working.
Short rationale: Confirms if emergency heating works; appliance state, not behavioral.

Description: Device activations that occur during rapid temperature drops and are followed by temperatures staying just above known freeze-damage levels indicate successful prevention of freeze damage.
Short rationale: Shows where pre-emptive protection worked; property-level damage avoidance.

Description: Frequent device activations at temperatures well above levels that have ever caused damage indicate overly conservative thermal thresholds.
Short rationale: Threshold tuning/false positives; control config, no behavior.

Description: If damage or leak episodes are associated with temperatures that were reached without any prior thermal device activation, alerts are not aggressive enough.
Short rationale: Alerts too lax vs damage; again control config.

Description: If low temperatures at night trigger fewer or later device activations than similar temperatures during the day, the system has time-of-day asymmetry in thermal protection.
Short rationale: Reveals that the system behaves differently at night vs day; mild inference about assumed occupancy patterns.

Description: Device activations that consistently happen immediately as temperature crosses a precise threshold are likely automatic, while those happening later or at inconsistent temperatures are likely manual.
Short rationale: Separates automatic threshold-based actions from delayed/manual ones, directly encoding human intervention times.

Description: If devices frequently activate at specific temperatures but temperature trajectories look similar in incidents with and without those activations, those devices may not materially affect thermal conditions.
Short rationale: Identifies devices with little impact; design/optimization signal.

Description: Segments whose temperatures frequently drop to low levels without any device ever activating are thermally unprotected areas.
Short rationale: Highlights structurally vulnerable segments; tied to specific property zones.

Description: If temperature-related device activations are frequent and temperature still oscillates around low levels, insulation is inadequate and cannot be compensated by heating alone.
Short rationale: Indicates need for insulation vs heating; system/design choice more than behavior.

Description: For hot-water circuits, device activations that occur when temperature exceeds a safe limit and are followed by cooling back into a normal range show effective overheat protection.
Short rationale: Confirms effective over-heat protection; safety feature behavior, not people.

Inference: Thermal cycling induced by control devices
Description: Repeated device activations that create regular temperature oscillations indicate that control logic is driving thermal cycling, which may stress materials.
Short rationale: Control-induced oscillations; control quality only.

Description: If temperature fluctuates widely around a setpoint and device activations are rapid and frequent, the thermal control loop is unstable or poorly tuned.
Short rationale: Unstable control loop identification; purely technical.

Description: By computing the average temperature change per activation for each device, the system can rank them by their thermal impact.
Short rationale: Average ΔT per activation per device; appliance effectiveness metric.

Inference: Identifying late activations relative to thermal risk
Description: For known thermal damage events, if device activations occur after temperatures remain below critical levels for a long time, they are classified as late activations.
Short rationale: Classifies activations as “late”; still about control timing vs risk, not identity.

Inference: Correlating temperature exposure with activation frequency
Description: Segments with long cumulative time below a low-temperature threshold and frequent temperature-related activations show that the system is working hard to protect them.
Short rationale: Shows which segments need frequent protection; segment-level risk, not behavioral.

Inference: Inferring wrongly placed temperature sensors from activation patterns
Description: If thermal devices often activate yet local temperature sensors show only modest changes, sensors may not be placed close enough to the thermally affected pipe sections.
Short rationale: Sensor placement quality; structural/installation.

Inference: Protective shutdown vs. continuing thermal stress
Description: For devices that shut off flow to protect against freezing, if temperatures in the isolated segment continue to drop after shutdown, the segment remains thermally exposed.
Short rationale: Whether shutdown actually protects segment; structural risk only.

Description: Some devices may activate only after temperature stays within a risky band for a certain duration; joint history reveals the implicit thermal pre-conditioning rule.
Short rationale: Reveals implicit dwell-time rules in the controller; logic, not user.

Description: If mild low temperatures trigger alerts while more extreme temperatures trigger alerts plus hardware actions, analyzing activation type and temperature shows a multi-level escalation design.
Short rationale: Shows multi-level escalation strategy; configuration insight.

Description: Device activations that occur at completely normal, stable temperatures and do not correspond to any thermal trend are likely driven by non-thermal factors such as moisture, flow, or manual override.
Short rationale: Explicitly surfaces actions driven by non-thermal factors (including manual overrides), giving a clearer picture of human/system decisions.

Inference: Learning safe thermal envelope from activation history
Description: The range of temperatures where no thermal-related device activations occur and no damage is observed defines an empirically safe thermal envelope for that system.
Short rationale: Empirical safe range for that system; property-level engineering info.
